Dramatic evidence is NET's "Black Journal", a monthly broadcast magazine
by, for and about black Americans, which premiered June 12. In the first program
Negro seniors at Harvard College comment on the Black Power movement, Vietnam,
and their future careers. This is compared with the views of Negroes
at Morehouse and Spellman Colleges in Atlanta. Reporters will visit Harlem
rep in New York City, to see how black history classes differ from conventional
mencan history, and comic Godfrey Cambridge joins Chicago's Second City
Troupe to present a satire called "It's In To Be Black". Also planned is a report
on a late breaking national news story and a review of the Negro press.
For the coming year, NET Journal plans programs on the rural poor in
Appalaclua, violence in the United States, the psychological conditioning of Negro
children to advancement, and life of the Puerto Rican in American cities. Debates
on national issues; consumer education, "Your Dollar's Worth"; "News in
Perspective"; and "Regional Report"; may be expected to continue their attention
to what are identified as "urban problems". Research is being conducted for
possible new public affairs programs on urban affairs and the American economy.
PBL has given major attention to issues of civil rights and urban crisis,
rogram segments include a discussion-confrontation between ordinary white
and Negro citizens m Chicago; exploration of urban problems with Urban League
director Whitney Young; an illustrative report on the conclusions of the President's
ommission on Rural Poverty; and a first-person report on a Negro GI returning
rom Vietnam and his conflict between providing for his family and joining the black
power cause. One complete program attempted to humanize the points made in
the Kerner Commission Report -- visiting a Harlem family, and injecting music
and other cultural material into a socially-oriented treatment of the report. (One
of the program segments, "Crisis in the Cities", won this year's television
Emmy Award. )
